moves.1. e4: An interesting endgame where I managed to pull out a victory.
moves.5. Bc4 e6 6. Bg5 f6 7. Bf4 Nc6 8. e5 f5: He doesn't want the position to open up yet.
moves.9. Bg5 Nce7 10. O-O: I want my rook in the center to open things up there.
moves.10... h6 11. Be3: The bishop is in the way there, but there aren't many places for it to go, and I didn't want to help him develop his Ng8.
moves.11... g5 12. d5: Making a push in the center
Protecting the pawn, I intended an eventual Re5.
moves.15... g4 16. Nh4: ? I failed to notice the knight was en prise.
Looking for a discovered check with exd7.
moves.19... O-O-O: ! Gets his king out of danger and his rook into action to protect d7.
moves.20... d5: Protecting the pawn and attacking the bishop, now e6 looks fragile.
moves.21. Bd3 Re7: So now he puts pressure on my pawn.
moves.22. Bxf5: Gains a pawn, protects my pawn, and opportunities to cause other problems in the kingside.
moves.26... Qh3: But now the queen is perilously close to my king.
moves.28. Rd2 Rge8 29. Bg6: There really was no way for black to avoid losing a rook.
moves.29... h4: Trying for counterplay on the kingside.
moves.30. Bxe8 hxg3: Sacrificing his rook for a dangerous attack.
moves.31. Qxe7: I thought I could withstand it.
moves.31... gxh2+ 32. Rxh2 Qg3+: I threaten mate, so he has to keep checking my king.
moves.33. Kf1 Ba6+ 34. Ree2 Qf3+ 35. Ke1 g3: Allows mate, but my king would have escaped eventually anyways.
moves.36. Qd7+ Kb8 37. Qd6+ Ka8 38. Bc6+: Black resigns, because of 38...Qxc6 39. Qxc6  Kb8 40. Rh8  Bc8 41. Rxc8#.  Undoubtedly my opponent and I made many mistakes, but it was a fun game.
